original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. Growing up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the former home of Bethlehem Steel, had a profound impact on me. My father, an engineer, would often explain how things worked, and we would collaborate on projects, such as model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built together - that's me behind the wheel, with my sister and best friend at the time. One day, when I was around 10 years old, my father came home and announced at the dinner table that our next project would be building a robot. A robot.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability encompasses the what, where, and how of seafood production. However, I believe the who and why are equally crucial. I'm interested in learning about the people behind my dinner choices and the impact I have on them, as well as the impact they have on me. I want to understand their motivations for fishing and how they rely on the ocean's resources for their livelihood. By grasping these aspects, we can transform our perception of seafood from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. This shift allows us to appreciate the seafood we're fortunate to eat. So, what do we call this approach? I propose the term 'restorative seafood.' While sustainability refers to the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative seafood is about replenishing and progressing.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel, the spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress, and the stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of Christmas past remain recognizable figures from Charles Dickens' work, more than a century after his death. His body of work is so striking that it has given rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens' writing that make it so special? Dickens' fiction is characterized by anticipation, built through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features kept his audience engaged. Initially, his stories were serialized in affordable literary journals, released a few chapters at a time, and later reprinted as books.

Twenty minutes later, that same child finds herself completely submerged in water.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. That technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before i talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3." we already saw that briefly yesterday. And what you can see is — it is actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.
polished: I'd like to discuss a cutting-edge technology currently being developed at Oxford, which we believe has the potential to revolutionize the creation of computer games and Hollywood movies. This technology involves simulating humans, complete with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control it. Before delving deeper into this technology, let's take a brief look at the current state of human characters in computer games. We have a clip from the game "Grand Theft Auto 3," which we touched on yesterday. As you can see, it's a highly acclaimed game, and one of the most successful of all time. Now, before I talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3.

original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished: Like many people worldwide, my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France earlier this summer. We were enthralled by the incredible athletes, the remarkable goals, and the clean, engaging games. Meanwhile, off the field, these women were advocating for equal pay, and in some countries, any pay at all for their sport. Due to our mild obsession, we sought to watch the games live and opted for a Spanish-speaking network in the US as our starting point. It wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend pointed out, "Why does it seem like all I'm seeing are commercials for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: I'd like to share with you the future of money, and to do so, let's delve into the fascinating story of the Yap culture in Micronesia during the early 1900s. The Yap's unique form of currency is particularly noteworthy. They utilized massive limestone discs known as rai stones. What's intriguing is that the Yap didn't physically exchange or move these stones, as they could be enormous - the largest weighing around four tons and measuring 12 feet in diameter. Instead, they kept track of ownership, recording who possessed a portion of which stone. A notable anecdote involves sailors transporting a stone across the ocean, only to encounter difficulties, resulting in the stone sinking.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: You've been falsely accused of a crime, with no means to prove your innocence. Insisting on your innocence may lead to a guilty verdict and execution. However, confessing, apologizing, and implicating others could secure your freedom. Do you give a false confession or risk a public hanging? This was the dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system prioritizing repentance over truth. Salem was established in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem. Battles with their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers were commonplace.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That's the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We're not yet able to print complex organs, but simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange, are already within our reach. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'll be discussing a phenomenon that has the potential to, and indeed is, changing the world - people power. To illustrate this concept, I'd like to share an anecdote, reminiscent of a Monty Python sketch. It's December 15, 2010. Imagine someone offers you a bet: you gaze into a crystal ball, and the future it reveals will be accurate, but you must share it with the world. Your curiosity gets the better of you, and you take the bet. You look into the crystal ball. One hour later, you find yourself in a national TV building, on a top-rated show, recounting the story.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23 years old, is at the pinnacle of his career. Christened the voice of a generation, he's producing classic songs at an incredible rate. However, a small minority of dissenters claim that Dylan is stealing other people's songs. Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, combines The Beatles' "White Album" with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." This mashup becomes an instant online sensation. The Beatles' record company responds with cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." The Grey Album is, in fact, a remix.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: That statement may seem obvious, but it's a crucial one. I first made that observation about 12 years ago, specifically in the context of developing countries. However, I'm aware that my audience today comes from diverse corners of the globe. If you were to visualize a map of your country, you'd likely notice that there are areas where good teachers are reluctant to go. Ironically, these are often the places where trouble originates. We're faced with a paradox: the most skilled educators tend to avoid the areas where they're needed most. In 1999, I initiated an experiment in New Delhi to address this issue, and it was remarkably straightforward.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished: Currently, most refugees reside in cities rather than in refugee camps, accounting for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. This urban presence necessitates a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Instead of investing in physical barriers, it would be more beneficial to allocate resources to programs empowering refugees to become self-sufficient. (applause) Although we often leave behind our possessions, our skills and knowledge remain. When given the opportunity to lead productive lives, refugees can not only support themselves but also contribute to the development of their host country. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished: I have two questions for you: whose shoulders do you stand on, and what do you stand for? I begin my poetry workshops with these questions because, at times, poetry can seem like a stagnant art form associated with old, white men who appear to have been born with an air of agelessness. I pose these questions to my students and then share my own responses, which can be summarized in three sentences: I am the daughter of black writers who are descended from freedom fighters who broke free from their chains and changed the world. They call me. I repeat these words as a mantra before every poetry performance, a ritual I was just practicing in the corner, making faces to myself. I am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about five years after graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue, known as the eight-foot bride, and i love sharing this experience with people, as everyone is always curious about the individuals behind such unconventional professions. (laughter)hello.i would paint myself white, stand on a box, place a hat or can at my feet, and when someone approached and dropped in money, i would hand them a flower — accompanied by intense eye contact. And if they declined the flower, i would express a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was not the first piece of human technology to enter space; that distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities during the final years of World War II. Although the V-2 rocket was not very effective, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. captured the technology and the scientists who developed it at the end of the war, utilizing them for their own projects.

original: I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an ipod — an ipod that contains wagner and mozart, pop diva christina aguilera, country singer josh turner, gangsta rap artist kirk franklin, concerti, symphonies and more and more. I'm a voracious reader, a reader who deals with ian mcewan down to stephanie meyer. I have read the twilight tetralogy. And one who lives for my home theater, a home theater where i devour dvds, video on demand and a lot of television. For me, "law & order: svu," tina fey and "30 rock" and "judge judy" — "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.
polished: As a cultural omnivore, my daily commute is made possible by my trusty iPod, which boasts an eclectic mix of Wagner and Mozart, pop sensation Christina Aguilera, country artist Josh Turner, and gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin, alongside concerti and symphonies. I'm an avid reader with a diverse taste, devouring works by Ian McEwan and Stephanie Meyer, including the Twilight tetralogy. My home theater is my sanctuary, where I indulge in DVDs, video on demand, and a wide range of television shows. I have a soft spot for "Law & Order: SVU," Tina Fey's "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy," where the drama is real.

original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors and people everywhere. So i'm pleased you are launching ted countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.
polished: [Citizens of the world,] we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale. Please stand by for a message from the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres. The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. A growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, is rising due to global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and people everywhere. I'm pleased you're launching TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us now join this race with the necessary political will and energy.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation, a straightforward term for a natural biological process, has been burdened by centuries of stigma, forcing many to discuss it in hushed tones. But why? As I speak, over 800 million women worldwide are experiencing their period. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains a subject often deemed "embarrassing" to discuss. From my personal experience and that of the women around me, I can attest that it's draining. It's draining to discreetly take out a pad from a brown paper bag, hastily stuffing it into a pocket during class, and rushing to the washroom as unobtrusively as possible. The rest of the text remains the same.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical ecosystems, they clean air, they clean water, they sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a huge diversity of species.
polished: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of Canada's boreal forest, the largest and most intact forest globally. Spanning across northern Canada, including Labrador, it is home to the George River caribou herd, the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world, with approximately 400,000 animals. Although I was unable to find one during my visit, the antlers serve as proof. The boreal region is blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands, which are globally one of the most endangered ecosystems. They are critical ecosystems that clean air and water, sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and support a huge diversity of species.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.
polished: Before the world of humans began, there existed a realm of the gods, comprising vast fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial expanse, bound together by their fraternal bond, as they had no family other than each other and were unaware of their parents' identities. One of the brothers, Deminan, stood out from the others due to his physical appearance. His skin was afflicted with painful scabs, leaving him to ponder the reason behind this singular affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended to his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck into Yaya's house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. Essentially, what the company was doing was creating a medical device where you would be able to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. So this was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also, it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.
polished: I had graduated seven years ago from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. Following my graduation, I attended a career fair on campus, where I secured an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there was limited information available about the company, but what I found was impressive. Essentially, Theranos was developing a medical device that could run an entire blood panel using just a finger-stick of blood. This innovation had the potential to make blood tests less painful, as it would eliminate the need for a large needle to be inserted into the arm. This concept was intriguing not only due to its reduced invasiveness but also its potential to open the door to predictive diagnostics.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began when I was four years old, when my family relocated from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. We lived among the Inuit in a small community of 200 Inuit people, where we were one of three non-Inuit families. Without the distractions of television, computers, radio, or even a telephone, I spent all my time outdoors with the Inuit, playing and learning. The snow and ice served as my playground, and the Inuit were my guides. This is where my fascination with the polar realm truly began.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent his nights in a grove of towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and engaged in hours of conversation around the campfire with his host and guide, renowned conservationist John Muir. Although Roosevelt was well-known for his love of the outdoors, Muir's invitation extended beyond a mere camping excursion: Yosemite was facing a grave threat. Despite being designated as protected land in 1864, the valley remained vulnerable to overdevelopment in 1903. This predicament was at the heart of a decades-long struggle to balance preservation and public use – a delicate balance that proved far easier to conceptualize than achieve.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. To avoid being misled, it's essential to assess a headline's credibility by examining the original research it reports on. We've created hypothetical research scenarios for each of these three headlines. Keep watching for the explanation of the first example, then pause at the headline to answer the question. These scenarios are simplified for clarity.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from Ethiopia. My mom asked, "What date should we put for their birthday?" I thought it was a ridiculous question, responding, "The day they were born, obviously?" However, my mom explained that neither of my brothers had a birth certificate, making it impossible to determine their exact birthdate. This revelation had a profound impact on me. Twenty years later, I'm still working on this issue, but now I'm trying to solve it on a global scale. So, what's the connection between birth certificates and international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine being able to plug your brain into a machine that would provide you with ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If given the choice, would you opt for such an existence? This is the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through his thought-provoking experiment, the Experience Machine. The experiment invites us to consider a world where scientists have developed a machine that simulates real life, guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and no pain. The catch is that you must permanently leave reality behind, but the difference would be almost imperceptible. Your experiences would be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural fluctuations would be replaced with an endless series of positive experiences. Sounds great, right?

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the released carbon go? Carbon operates within a natural cycle, present in all living organisms: in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb it. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life transforms into rock and fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, like volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, also release prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release approximately 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year, while the natural cycle of carbon continues with plants and other living things dying, and new ones growing and reabsorbing the carbon.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even nature's most unappealing creatures hold significant secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches approaching them? One of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Notably, cockroaches can self-stabilize while running over rough terrain. When we equipped them with a jet pack or subjected them to a perturbation like an earthquake, we found that their remarkably tuned legs allowed them to self-stabilize without relying on brainpower. They can navigate complex terrain, such as grass, with ease and without destabilizing. We discovered a new behavior where, due to their shape, they automatically roll onto their side to pass through a test section of artificial grass. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
